author: @rexphoto4274
text: 00:07 Knee Bhai's Classifier 02:12 To compute the value Y in a classification problem, the probability of Y given all the features x1, x2, x3, x4, ..., xn needs to be found. 04:21 Calculate the output based on the highest probability of Y and all the features 06:26 Determine whether a person is going to play tennis based on outlook and temperature. 08:24 The probability of yes is calculated based on the value of 'outlook' when it is sunny. 10:25 The probability of playing given sunny and hot weather is 2/9 multiplied by 2/9 multiplied by 9/14 12:15 The probability of 'no' is greater than the probability of 'yes'. 14:09 Name bias classifier probability gets applied based on Bayes theorem

author: @muskanrath7125
text: can you please explain again why did you skip P(Today)? Because if we try to express P(Today)= P(Sunny)*P(Hot) and then P(Sunny)=P(Sunny|Yes)*P(Yes) + P(Sunny|No)*P(No) and P(SHot)=P(Hot|Yes)*P(Yes) + P(Hot|No)*P(No). And when i tried computing this, i got P(today) as 20/196.

author: @ihbarddx
text: Had you used the denominator in the formula, you would have got something slightly different - and the Y/N conditional probabilities would not sum to 1. This is normal for Naive Bayes - and why it's known as a "Bad" estimator. The point should have been addressed, rather than covered up. Otherwise, nice presentation.

author: @sagarhire8228
text: Fundamental assumption in  Naive bayes is that, it consider  "Features are Conditionally Independent " .  and therefore  we  can obtain P(class_lable | X) is directly proportional to  P(class_label) *  ( multiplication of individual probabilities of xi(features)  given class label) where xi belongs to query point
